utterances: Amara La Negra says she really wants to be a role model for Afro-Latinas coming up today.
She just signed a multimillion-dollar record deal.
She's got a doll collection in the works, and she says - fingers crossed - she'll be on the big screen, too.
And she ended our interview by shouting out the Afro-Latina in her life who made it all possible.
Mommy.
Mommy, I love you so much.
Thank you.
I can't wait to go home to give you a hug.
I miss you so much.
OK.
(Laughter).
Shereen Marisol Meraji, NPR News.
(SOUNDBITE OF SONG, ""SE QUE SOY"")
(Singing in Spanish).
This is DAY TO DAY from NPR News, I'm Alex Chadwick.
Hurricane Paul is now downgraded to tropical storm Paul - that lessens the threat to Mexico's Pacific Coast.
It's a familiar pattern doing this hurricane season.
The season isn't over really till the end of next month, but plainly it's not going to fulfill dire predictions made by the National Hurricane Center.
Here is NOAA's Conrad Lautenbacher back in May.
NOAA is predicting an above normal hurricane season.
With 13 to 16 named storms, of which eight to 10 are predicted to become hurricanes, and four to six of those hurricanes are predicted to become major at Category three strength or higher.
We are joined now MIT Professor Kerry Emanuel, he's the Author of Divine Wind: The History and Science of Hurricanes.
Kerry welcome back to DAY TO DAY, what happened to 2006?
Well it certainly turned out to be quiet to most everyone's relief.
And the question is why were the forecast wrong?
Well, one thing to begin with is that the forecast have never been really good.
I mean they are certainly skillful, but if you look at the whole history of forecasts, there are many years with fairly large errors.
And one can try to do a postmortem on the season and try to attribute certain actual outcomes to certain causes, but that's dangerous.
So for example this year - what happened, which was not predicted, was that we had a weak El Nino develop in the Pacific.
And that's known to suppress the Atlantic hurricanes.
And that certainly accounts for part, maybe most, of the lack of activity.
But I have to emphasize at the same time, that from one year to the next there is an awful lot of variability that just has to be called random.
Well, there is still six weeks left in this hurricane season, what is the history of big storms from this point in the season on?
They are pretty unusual.
Except quite far south from the Caribbean, you can very strong hurricanes that affect the Central America, for example, that form and our reach maximum intensity in the Caribbean.
But it's very unusual to have a big Atlantic storm affecting the United States at this time of year.
You know when we spoke, about a year ago, after Katrina - you noted then that global climate change is associated with strengthening hurricanes.
Global warming hasn't gone away.
If anything, I think, scientists would say there are more signals of it.
So where is that factor?
Well it certainly does factor in, but global warming is just one of many, many things that goes on, that affects hurricanes.
So to take a simpler problem, what about temperature itself?
Anybody living in any particular place in the United States knows the temperature goes up and down.
And almost none of that going up and down has anything to do with global warming.
You have to look at long term averages to see that.
So for example, it might turn out that this year in Boston, where I live, is colder than last year.
I don't know that but it might very well turn out to be the case and we would not accept that as a proof that global warming isn't occurring.
You'll just be grateful you haven't seen a hurricane this year.
That's right.
Kerry Emanuel's is a Professor at MIT he teaches Earth, Atmospheric and Planetary Sciences there Kerry Emanuel thank you.
You're quite welcome.
Yesterday, the Joint Congressional Committee on Inaugural Ceremonies announced the lineup for January 20th.

In addition to Barack Obama's inaugural address, there will be performances by Aretha Franklin, Yitzhak Perlman and Yo-yo Ma, poetry read by Elizabeth Alexander and an invocation by the Reverend Rick Warren.
He's the pastor of Saddleback Church, the author of the best-selling book, ""The Purpose-Driven Life,"" and to some, a force for intolerance.
Warren opposes abortion and gay marriage.

In this past election, he worked for passage of Proposition 8, the California ballot initiative that amended that state's constitution to read (unintelligible) marriage between a man and woman is valid or recognized in California.
At a news conference in Chicago this morning, a reporter asked the president-elect about the furious reaction from many progressives, gays and lesbians who supported him.
He responded by saying he remains a fierce advocate of gay rights.
Well, I don't know, but a lot of people are very obsessed with them.
Okay.
NPR legal affairs correspondent Nina Totenberg.
Three weeks later, Molly was rescued.
And then adopted by a woman named Kaye Harris who runs a birthday party pony business.
But that's only the beginning of Molly's story.
One day, while out in the pasture, she was attacked by a pit bull who bit her on her leg.
For a while, Molly managed on three legs.
Then Kaye Harris took her to veterinarian Dr. Rustin Moore.
And the options were really, probably really only two.
One was to either euthanize or humanely destroy Molly or to do an amputation and fit her with a prosthesis.
Amputation surgery on horses is rare.
But after observing Molly for a few days, Dr. Moore decided she was a good candidate because she was small and because she had adapted so well on just three legs.
She was pretty smart.
She would get up and lie down frequently.
She would switch sides.
She was able to do all this not using that affected leg, and so she had a good demeanor about her and seemed to be a fighter.
Pam Kaster's book includes photographs of Molly from her rescue from Katrina, her surgery, and from the fitting of her artificial leg.
Since this is a children's book, at the bottom of some of the pages are definitions of big words.
Pam Kaster describes Molly as quiet and demure, but also, determined.
Molly sometimes likes to wear her limb and sometimes she does not.
And if she has her limb on, and she thinks it's time to have it taken off, she'll go up to Ms. Kaye and hit her it with it.
And Ms. Kaye knows it is time to take the limb off.
Molly and Ms. Kaye have got a very, very close relationship.
Pam Kaster thinks Molly's story is an example of how, three years later, those who survived Katrina are rebuilding their lives.
This tragedy has given us all different directions to go in and new ways to start over and to look at life.

Kirby Larson and Mary Nethery hope their book, the ""Two Bobbies,"" will give meaning to the tragedy to small children and adults who have never been to the Gulf Coast, so that people don't forget about it.
Unfortunately, we have really short memories, and this is old news now.
It happened in 2005, and there's still so much need there.
One final note, Bob Cat died earlier this year just before the ""Two Bobbies"" was published.
Molly the Pony is now a therapeutic friend to the elderly and children in hospitals.
Elizabeth Blair, NPR News.
You're listening to All Things Considered from NPR News.
Our business news starts with lower gasoline prices.
The price of gasoline has fallen to its lowest level of the summer, just as vacation season is coming to an end.
The Energy Department says the average price of gasoline has dropped nearly $0.20 a gallon in the last three weeks.
But the price of diesel fuel has barely budged.
NPR's Scott Horsley reports.
If the Energy Department had said a year ago that the average price of gasoline would be $2.84 a gallon, drivers might have screamed highway robbery.
But now, that price almost seems like a bargain.
At an Arco Station in San Diego, Robert Lopez(ph) and Cheney Davis(ph) were just happy to see any price on the pump that didn't start with the number three.
I feel wonderful about it.
Yeah.
It's, I'm glad to see this happening.
I don't think that's so bad, because it was, like, $3.30.
So it's not bad at all.
Unleaded regular is selling for $2.96 a gallon at this station, and cars are lined up three-deep to buy it.
The station's price is about $0.15 below the average for California, but its still not low enough for customer Lisa Paponte(ph).
They can go down a whole lot more.
We need cheaper gas prices.
Still, Paponte is lucky she's not buying diesel fuel.
At the So Cal Truck Stop a few miles away, near the Port of San Diego, diesel sells for $3.21 a gallon, or about $0.25 more than the Arco price for gasoline.
Trucker Mark Gann's(ph) rig is a diesel guzzler.
About five miles a gallon, sometimes six on a good day, going downhill.
Gann has just dropped off a load of frozen chickens on his weekly run from Arkansas, and he's topping up his tank for the trip home with a load of produce.
He figures his fuel bill runs between $1,000.00 and $1,500.00 a week.
Probably in excess of 100 gallons a day.
That's serious burning.
There it goes right there.
We're just going to kind of even it up to 100 gallons and then go on up the hill and get our produce and head back to Arkansas.
Even as gasoline prices have fallen sharply in the last few weeks, the average price of diesel fuel has stayed within a few pennies of its summertime peak.
